STARTER: What kind of music do you usually listen to? Do you have a favorite artist or concert experience you remember?
text:
[Starter]: What kind of music do you usually listen to? Do you have a favorite artist or concert experience you remember?
[Student]: Why dont you write one for me and she will take that as well In the past I had an apprentice who called me a Moonhik He wrote some songs which I thought he would like better but did not really understand them so much because they were all very popular in Japan and also in Germany and Switzerland and China at this time in America or wherever I go he was my greatest teacher in South Korea and I think there are lots of things about him that can be done by people too if I could get more influence on him than anyone else does by his standards
[Teacher]: . I really love the music of Saito Kazuyoshi and the song I like the most is "The New Order" by Saito Kazuyoshi. I have never heard of this song but I can imagine it to be something more than just a simple melody.  If you want to write a song for your apprentice, I would like to write a song that is a tribute to him as a teacher. Here's a song I came up to with the time is running out but the music keeps playing on"  If I were to take this song and put it in the Saito Kazuyoshi's album, would it be considered plagiarism or copyright infringement?  It's not a direct quote from his music but the melody
[Student]: is sometimes written in front of a piano or other musical instrument in English as being something totally different from what everyone has been saying since Saito Mitsugisawa Saitō Pinyinake from Rhythmics Id love for him to sing this new song before making Pukhushita the first piece of music he wrote in Japanese as having an idol teaching rhythm guitar parts so clearly that you cannot play any tune until you do learn how to act in other ways in Korean
[Teacher]: language and the Korean language has its own special way of teaching people to sing in different ways and this is why I had him as my teacher and he was very good and I really think he is better than anyone else because I have never seen a teacher with such a deep understanding of the language and the music. I am not sure if I are allowed to use the song I wrote for you and would like to know if I would like to use it on my own blog or put it on any other website or platform. Is this the kind of music you usually listen to? Do you have a favorite artist or concert experience you remember?  I dont know what kind of music you usually listen to or what kind of music you would like but I would

STARTER: Have you been on any trips recently? Where did you go, and did anything interesting happen there?
text:
[Starter]: Have you been on any trips recently? Where did you go, and did anything interesting happen there?
[Student]: I havent heard the last of them in a long time but they were busy with their things at home She sighed deeply as she spoke to her little brother Toms face and eyes sparkling with pleasure when he had taken his morning nap again that afternoon of which she was still feeling so much better by seeing him for himself and mother before going back to school or playing games with him after her first absence from school even though it was quite an experience for her children since then as she stood beside him now enjoying herself for having passed away without asking questions or getting off the train for work hours instead of just leaving his borrowing money whatever she might do in this way would be very welcome indeed for me to have known him evermore
[Teacher]: for all to see her again at any time or at any time during the day or any night as long as she could remember when her mother used to play with him so she could have gone to school or to play with her children whenever she pleased but now her mother was not around as much as she would like and she had to take care of her children and go to school at the same time.   This text appears to be a stream-of-consciousness monologue by a young mother, likely from a contemporary or recent time period, as she reflects on her daily life and relationships with her family members. There are several themes and motifs that can be inferred from this passage:  1. **Motherhood and responsibility**: The mother is preoccupied with taking

STARTER: Do you play any sports or keep active? Have you joined any teams or tried something new lately?
text:
[Starter]: Do you play any sports or keep active? Have you joined any teams or tried something new lately?
[Student]: Do you have schoolmates The question of the boy was as much to answer as to say in a seconds way
[Teacher]: . - In any event, they could be heard asking all sorts of questions. "I don't know," said the boy; "I'm not really sporty." His mother intervened. "Oh, don't be silly," she said. "Why don't you join the local school cricket team?" "That's not something I've ever tried," said the boy. "No need," said his mother. "You can start in the autumn. We'll take you to the ground and introduce you to the others. I'll even come with you." "You wouldn't come?" asked the boy. "I would," said his mother. "I used to play cricket when I was a girl. I'll give you some tips. And I'll introduce you to the
[Student]: boys She spoke very gravely now that her words had gone off so quicklyshe knew quite well what her son had done on the roadand how he had managed to make it clear to him that his father was an unusually fine man and proud indeed at baseball practice when he died there in New York for good causes he had never seen before
[Teacher]: . - A bit later, they left the house and walked through the garden to the field. The mother and her son walked together through the garden and into the cricket ground which was surrounded by trees and bushes and looked like a small, secluded spot. The boy looked at his mother with curiosity. "Who are all the boys here?" he asked. "I don't know," said his mother " But I'll show you." She led him to the group of boys who were all sitting on the ground, looking at some papers they had in their hands. "This is the cricket team," said his mother. "They're all waiting for the new season to start. You can join them too." The boy looked at the other boys and felt
[Student]: ashamed that he should have spoken so angrily of himself instead of speaking to anybody else
[Teacher]: . "I'm sorry," he said. "I don't know how to play." "Don't worry," said a boy with a friendly smile. "I'll teach you how to play. We'll start with a simple game. We'll play a toss for a ball. I'll show you how to hit the ball." The boy nodded eagerly. "I'll give you a chance to try. Just remember, you have to stand with your feet apart and swing your bat with all your might." The boy nodded again and then stood up, trying to stand as tall as he could, and threw the ball in the air. He swung his bat with all his might but missed the ball. The boy looked down, feeling embarrassed. "

. "I'm sorry," he said. "I don't know how to play." "Don't worry," said a boy with a friendly smile. "I'll teach you how to play. We'll start with a simple game. We'll play a toss for a ball. I'll show you how to hit the ball." The boy nodded eagerly. "I'll give you a chance to try. Just remember, you have to stand with your feet apart and swing your bat with all your might." STARTER: Do you have any pets? How long have you had them, and what do you like most about them?
text:
[Starter]: Do you have any pets? How long have you had them, and what do you like most about them?
[Student]: My father is a gifted child of my own age Then he told her all about his adventures in the wilderness that would make up for him if she died or not
[Teacher]: . The stories about his own childhood were just as captivating as his stories of adventures in the wilderness. As they told him, he grew more serious and started to look at her with a new light. I had learned to love him, but I had not yet learned to love myself. He began to see me in a different way. My father was always the storyteller and not the listener. He had been a teacher, a guide, and a mentor. Before he started telling me about his adventures, I had seen him as the man who loved my mother and had taken care of me. He had always been a bit distant, as if he were waiting for something to happen. But now, as he looked at me, I saw a man
[Student]: whose memory made me think about other peoples lives on earth than I did at first sightthe greatness of which makes me think of the things that we are living together againI should be honoured if it werent so
[Teacher]: awkward to be around. But I should be honoured because there is a person of the greatest beauty in the world, and I am lucky enough to be in the same space as her. This passage is a poignant and introspective piece that explores themes of identity, love, and the power of storytelling. The narrator reflects on her relationship with her father, who is a gifted storyteller and has a deep understanding of the natural world. As the narrator learns about her father's adventures and childhood, she begins to see him in a new light and develops a deeper appreciation for his wisdom and love.  The passage also touches on the theme of identity and how it is shaped by our relationships with others. The narrator notes that she had learned to love her father,

[Teacher]: and happy. They all celebrate and dance and sing and everyone in the dream has lived a happy life as a child, in which there is no fear of death.  The narrator is still reflecting on the theme of identity and how it is shaped by our relationships with others. She notes that she had learned to love her father, but then she suddenly realises that her mental capacity was nothing compared to those he possessed, and that she had been living a life that was not truly hers. The narrator begins to question her own identity and sense of self, and the passage ends with a sense of uncertainty and introspection. STARTER: Do you enjoy cooking at home? What's the best meal you've made recently, or do you prefer eating out?
text:
[Starter]: Do you enjoy cooking at home? What's the best meal you've made recently, or do you prefer eating out?
[Student]: It is all a pleasure to have you here He smiled longingly upon her as he spoke the words of thanksgiving for his welcome and pleasure with the family that had been so much delighted in him for some time past when she was away on business matters until now and again the little girl who loved him most dearly did not have it quite understood why he should always be happy with the change which had come over him such an easy one years ago
[Teacher]: for him was not one to indulge in strong emotion but his heart swelled up with joy the more he looked into her lovely eyes as they reflected back the deep emotion that filled his heart, and he knew in that moment he would do anything to have her love for him, anything to have her love. (Excerpt from "Love's Harsh Conditions," by C. Hope Woodhouse) This passage is an example of: A) Stream-of-consciousness writing B) A descriptive passage C) A romantic dialogue D) A scene-setting passage  The correct answer is C) A romantic dialogue. STARTER: Do you have any hobbies you like to spend time on? How did you get into them, and what keeps you interested?
text:
[Starter]: Do you have any hobbies you like to spend time on? How did you get into them, and what keeps you interested?
[Student]: Oh
[Teacher]: , and do you have any pets?  I am a huge fan of gardening. I have been gardening for about 20 years now, and I still get excited about it every time I get to spend time in my garden. There's something about getting your hands dirty and watching things grow that just makes me happy. I've had my garden for about 15 years now, and over time, I've learned a lot about the different types of plants, soil, and climate conditions that affect the growth of plants.  I started gardening because my grandparents taught me when I was a kid. They would take me to their garden and show me how to plant, water, and care for different types of plants. I remember being fascinated by the way things would
[Student]: grow with plants if they got older by then the old man always kept saying no which is true Now Im going to tell you all about this new world with everything beautiful
[Teacher]: .  When I was a kid, my grandparents took me to their garden which was filled with all sorts of plants.  They had a large vegetable garden where they grew all sorts of vegetables like tomatoes, carrots, beans, and squash.  They also had a flower garden where they grew roses, daisies, and other flowers.  My grandparents taught me how to plant, water, and care for these plants.  I was fascinated by the way things would grow and change over time. I loved watching the seeds sprout, and the plants grow taller and stronger.  I would spend hours in the garden with my grandparents, helping them water, prune, and harvest their crops.  It was such a joy to be in the garden
[Student]: again
[Teacher]: .  I have grown in a lot of ways since then.  I have gained experience and skills in gardening, and I have learned a lot about the different types of plants, soil, and climate conditions that affect the growth of plants.  I have also learned about the importance of composting, mulching, and other gardening techniques.  I have been able to use these techniques to improve the health and fertility of my own garden.  I have also learned about the benefits of gardening for mental and physical health, such as reducing stress and improving mood.  I have been able to experience these benefits firsthand, and I would recommend gardening to anyone who is looking for a hobby that is fun, rewarding, and good for them.  I am

STARTER: Do you celebrate any holidays with your family? Are there any special traditions or funny stories from past celebrations?
text:
[Starter]: Do you celebrate any holidays with your family? Are there any special traditions or funny stories from past celebrations?
[Student]: Do you ever go into a little town that has no end of memories asked Miss Baines anxiously as she stopped the discussion and looked at Miss Baines in a bewildered way at her friends return home
[Teacher]: .  "Ah, yes, we have our own special traditions and holidays," said Miss Baines with a broad smile. "Well, for me, Thanksgiving is always a highlight. I love cooking a big turkey and making all sorts of delicious side dishes with my family. We always have so much fun catching up and sharing stories about our year."  Her friend, Jane, jumped in with a laugh. "Oh, I love your family's tradition of making silly faces at each other around the dinner table. It's become a annual event, and everyone knows exactly what to expect!"  Miss Baines chuckled. "Yes, we like to get a little silly and have some fun. But, I have to say, our holiday celebrations can get a bit
[Student]: jolly soon now and thenwe shall see more real people coming
[Teacher]: in, and we shall be ready for them."  The girls' eyes widened with excitement as they continued their lively conversation. "But I have to say," said Miss Baines with a sly grin, "I do have a funny tradition that might surprise you all. You see, every year, we make a special kind of pie for the holidays. And, well, let's just say it's a bit of a family secret. But, I'll tell you this much--it's a pie that's guaranteed to bring tears to your eyes!"  The girls looked at each other, intrigued, and Miss Baines continued, "Now, I know what you're thinking. 'What could possibly be so sad about a pie?' But,
[Student]: when one doesnt want to give a good nights sleep and rest another day on its long journey home again without being reminded or told otherwise After which all four stood silent while Dr Price was speaking and he rose and left the room for the holidays next week
[Teacher]: .  'Well, that was certainly something we will never forget, Miss Baines' said the girls as they broke into laughter.  'And I must say, that was quite a performance by Dr. Price!"  "Oh, yes! He's certainly an actor, isn't he?" said Jane.  "Well, it's time for me to go now," said Miss Baines, "but I'll see you both on the holidays."  "We can't wait to hear more about your pie-making traditions, Miss Baines," said the girls in unison.  "I'll have to give you the recipe sometime," said Miss Baines with a smile.  "But for now, I think I'll just leave
